column2: "An intellectual movement. . . Offering a challenge to any theory that makes a truth claim" (Martin, 2002).
column3: Martin, J., & Culture, O. (2002). Mapping the terrain. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications.

column2: "the philosophical stance informing the methodology and this providing a context for the process and grounding its logic and criteria." (Crotty, 1998) A stance or philosophy (Strauss & Corbin, 1998)
column3: Strauss, A., & Corbin, J. (1998). Basics of qualitative research: Techniques and procedures for developing grounded theory, 2nd ed (Vol. xiii). Thousand Oaks, CA, US: Sage Publications, Inc.

column2: "the strategy, plan of action, process, or design lying behind the choice and use of particular methods and linking the choice of methods to the desired outcomes" (Crotty 1998) "A way of thinking about and studying social reality" (Strauss & Corbin, 1998)
column3: Crotty, M. (1998). The Foundations of Social Research: Meaning and Perspective in the Research Process. SAGE.; Strauss, A., & Corbin, J. (1998). Basics of qualitative research: Techniques and procedures for developing grounded theory, 2nd ed (Vol. xiii). Thousand Oaks, CA, US: Sage Publications, Inc.

column2: "the techniques or procedures used to gather and analyse data related to some research question or hypothesis" (Crotty 1998)
column3: Crotty, M. (1998). The Foundations of Social Research: Meaning and Perspective in the Research Process. SAGE.

column2: A group of epistemologies that are defined by their using language to describe reality directly, "unproblematically" (Martin, 2002)
column3: Martin, J., & Culture, O. (2002). Mapping the terrain. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications.

column2: A group of methods "that produces findings not arrived at by statistical procedures or other means of quantification ." (Strauss & Corbin, 1998)
column3: Strauss, A., & Corbin, J. (1998). Basics of qualitative research: Techniques and procedures for developing grounded theory, 2nd ed (Vol. xiii). Thousand Oaks, CA, US: Sage Publications, Inc.

column2: A group of methods which analyzes primarily data that is counted or described numerically. Quantitative methods are sometimes seen as being objective/positivist, large-N, generalizable studies, but none of those things are necessarily true of quantitative (Martin, 2002)
column3: Martin, J., & Culture, O. (2002). Mapping the terrain. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications.

column2: A method in which an individual case (or instance) is studied in detail. (Abbot, 2004)
column3: Abbott, A. (2004). Methods of Discovery: Heuristics for the Social Sciences (Contemporary Societies Series). W. W. Norton & Company.

column2: A method in which the researcher gathers data by personal interaction (Abbot, 2004)
column3: Abbott, A. (2004). Methods of Discovery: Heuristics for the Social Sciences (Contemporary Societies Series). W. W. Norton & Company.

column2: A method in which the researcher records data about their own experience in a culture or group.
a methodology that aims to describe a certain social reality "richly and deeply" (Martin, 2002) without a requirement to abstrat that knowledge to other contexts
column3: Martin, J., & Culture, O. (2002). Mapping the terrain. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications.

column2: A methodology that assumes that a researcher (an outsider) can use the literature and existing theory to choose appropriate research questions and frameworks to use to describe a social or cultural object (Martin, 2002)
column3: Martin, J., & Culture, O. (2002). Mapping the terrain. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications.

column2: A methodology that focuses on questioning and evaluating social meaning, rather than simply describing it. Not to be confused with the literary method by the same name (which applies critical theory to literary hermenutics)
A methodology that prioritizes generating knowledge that can inform or test broader theory, allow for predictions in novel contexts, or contribute to theories of causality (Martin, 2002)
column3: Martin, J., & Culture, O. (2002). Mapping the terrain. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications.

column2: A methodology that requires the researcher to "learn, as far as is humanly possible, to view things from an . . . Insider point of view." (Martin, 2002)
column3: Martin, J., & Culture, O. (2002). Mapping the terrain. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications.

column2: A model or perspective that helps an observer make sense of the world (or a part of it). (Crotty, 1998; Kuhn, 1962)
column3: Crotty, M. (1998). The Foundations of Social Research: Meaning and Perspective in the Research Process. SAGE.; Kuhn, T. S. (1962). The Structure of Scientific Revolutions Vol. The University of Chicago Press.

column2: A pracitical implementation of an ontology. i.e. biological classification by Kingdom through species.
A researcher's awareness of their own background, experience of, influence on, and interpretation of the object of study.
A theoretical perspective that opposes gender inequalities in social reality and institutions

A theoretical perspective that asserts that social reality is shaped by politica, economic, cultural, ethinic, and gender values. (Lincoln & Guba, 1994) opposes the descriptive tradition of social science, focusing instead in questioning and evaluating social realities.
column3: Guba, E. G., & Lincoln, Y. S. (1994). Competing paradigms in qualitative research. Handbook of Qualitative Research, 2(163â€“194), 105.

column2: An attempt to answer a research question with more than one method. Usually used to describe studies or research agendas which use both qualitative and quantitative methods.
An epistemological description of a truth that exists entirely independent of observers.
An epistemological description of truth or meaning that exists in the observer (the subject) only. (Crotty, 1998)
column3: Crotty, M. (1998). The Foundations of Social Research: Meaning and Perspective in the Research Process. SAGE.

column2: An epistemology that asserts that "meanings are constructed by human beings as they engage with the world they are interpreting" (Crotty, 1998)
column3: Crotty, M. (1998). The Foundations of Social Research: Meaning and Perspective in the Research Process. SAGE.

column2: An epistemology that asserts that all meaningful knowledge comes from empirical data.
An epistemology that asserts that any meaning attached to an object is held within and defined by the observer (the subject).
An epistemology(/theoretical perspective?) that asserts that culture cannot be understood independently from the structures it exists in
An epistemology that asserts that knowledge comes from sensory experience
An epistemology that asserts that meaning is constructed, shared, and evolved by groups of humans, not individuals (Crotty, 1998)
column3: Crotty, M. (1998). The Foundations of Social Research: Meaning and Perspective in the Research Process. SAGE.

column2: An epistemology that asserts that relies on empirical data for knowledge and acknolwedges that the the values, knowledge, and beliefs of the researcher can influence observations.
An epistemology(/theoretical perspective?) that asserts that social artifacts and behavior only acquire meaning when it is assigned to them in interaction (Abbot 2004)
column3: Abbott, A. (2004). Methods of Discovery: Heuristics for the Social Sciences (Contemporary Societies Series). W. W. Norton & Company.

column2: An explanation or model of phenomena that has been inferred from and supported by empirical evidence. "A set of well-developed concepts related through statements of relationship, which together constitute an integrated framework that can be used to explain or predict phenomena" (Strauss & Corbin, 1998)
column3: Strauss, A., & Corbin, J. (1998). Basics of qualitative research: Techniques and procedures for developing grounded theory, 2nd ed (Vol. xiii). Thousand Oaks, CA, US: Sage Publications, Inc.

column2: An ontology that "focuses on the processes of becoming" and defines social reality by how it came to be. (Martin, 2002)
column3: Martin, J., & Culture, O. (2002). Mapping the terrain. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications.

column2: An ontology that treats all reality (even social reality) as existing independent of observation or interpretation.
interpretation of text and other communication.
Recording data in "richly detailed accounts" (Martin, 2002)
column3: Martin, J., & Culture, O. (2002). Mapping the terrain. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications.

column2: research that aims to explain the "laws" (or patterns and regularities) of the natural world. (Crotty, 1998)
column3: Crotty, M. (1998). The Foundations of Social Research: Meaning and Perspective in the Research Process. SAGE.

column2: Research that aims to understand individuals
see instead: constructionism
see instead: interpretivism
see instead: mixed methods
see instead: mixed methods
see instead: mixed methods
see instead: objectivity. (objectivism in use to describe the political philosophy of Ayn Rand)

The idea that socially constructed meaning can build up on top of other socially constructed meaning, creating layers of socially constructed meaning that distances the subject from the object. (Crotty, 1998)
column3: Crotty, M. (1998). The Foundations of Social Research: Meaning and Perspective in the Research Process. SAGE.

column2: The idea, central to constructionism, that when a mind becomes aware of something, it "reaches out to, and into that object;" the "interdependence of subject and world" (Crotty 1998). Also described as the mind's ability to form representations of an object.
column3: Crotty, M. (1998). The Foundations of Social Research: Meaning and Perspective in the Research Process. SAGE.

column2: The process of translating a research question into a study-- choices about what data to collect in pursuit of a question (Martin, 2002)
column3: Martin, J., & Culture, O. (2002). Mapping the terrain. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications.

column2: The thing that is being understood or observed
The thing that is doing the understanding or observation
What is knowledge, and how do we know what it is?
What is? What things exist, how are they related, and how can we classify them?
When people treat their understanding as the truth, their ideas influence social reality. (Crotty, 1998) Treating an object of study as if it can be objectively known (Martin, 2002)
column3: Crotty, M. (1998). The Foundations of Social Research: Meaning and Perspective in the Research Process. SAGE.; Martin, J., & Culture, O. (2002). Mapping the terrain. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications.

column2: a methodology that relies on sampling participants from a larger population of interest and asking questions. Responses usually used to make inferences about the larger population
a methodology that tests a hypothesis about a treatment using a procedure.
A methodology that attempts to illustrate or replicate real world phenomena or systems using mathematic equations.
A methodology applied when few relevant cases are accessible to study; usually a comparitve, qualitative study of a small number of cases.
A methodology that uses many cases, often for the purposes of quantitative analysis.
A methodology that focuses on trying to explain the reasons for observed phenomena.
An explanatory program that attempts to translate phenomena into a language that others can understand
An explanatory prgram that attempts to understand and communicate phenomena using patterns. History does this.
An explanatory program that attempts "to separate more and more clearly the effects of different potential interventions or causes from one another." (Abbot, 2004)
column3: Abbott, A. (2004). Methods of Discovery: Heuristics for the Social Sciences (Contemporary Societies Series). W. W. Norton & Company.

column2: A methodology that studies texts and generally uses coding to convert qualitative data (texts) into quantitative data (counts and distributions of codes)
a methodology that studies language (and other semiotic representations) and its use to describe and shape social reality.
A theoretical perspective that analyzes direct experience, intentionally putting aside cultural interpretations of them (Crotty, 1998)
column3: Crotty, M. (1998). The Foundations of Social Research: Meaning and Perspective in the Research Process. SAGE.

column2: "theory that was derived from data, systematically gathered and analyzed through the research process." (Strauss & Corbin, 1998). Often used as a name for a method of arriving at grounded theory, developed by Glaser and Strauss (1998), that involves directly constructing theory from data, usually without reading existing theory beforehand.
column3: Strauss, A., & Corbin, J. (1998). Basics of qualitative research: Techniques and procedures for developing grounded theory, 2nd ed (Vol. xiii). Thousand Oaks, CA, US: Sage Publications, Inc.; Glaser, B. G., & Strauss, A. L. (2009). The Discovery of Grounded Theory: Strategies for Qualitative Research. Transaction Publishers.

column2: An epistemology* that asserts that meaning is created by social interaction, but interpreted, modified, and acted on individually. (Crotty, 1998) *Crotty describes it ias a theoretical perspective, but given its scope, it seems to fit the definition of an epistemology.
column3: Crotty, M. (1998). The Foundations of Social Research: Meaning and Perspective in the Research Process. SAGE.

column2: A theoretical perspective that focuses on the outcomes of a phenomenon (Crotty, 1998)
column3: Crotty, M. (1998). The Foundations of Social Research: Meaning and Perspective in the Research Process. SAGE.

column2: A theoretical perspective that identifies and interprets social practice and ritual (Crotty, 1998)
column3: Crotty, M. (1998). The Foundations of Social Research: Meaning and Perspective in the Research Process. SAGE.

column2: a theory that identifies and interprets behavior as a series of moves by players in a game (Crotty, 1998)
column3: Crotty, M. (1998). The Foundations of Social Research: Meaning and Perspective in the Research Process. SAGE.

column2: see instead : symbolic interactionism
A theory that asserts that social practice and social roles are being continuously reworked by the actors in them (Crotty, 1998)
column3: Crotty, M. (1998). The Foundations of Social Research: Meaning and Perspective in the Research Process. SAGE.

column2: A thoery that identifies and interprets the categories and means of classifying people use (Crotty, 1998) [esp. deviance?]
column3: Crotty, M. (1998). The Foundations of Social Research: Meaning and Perspective in the Research Process. SAGE.

column2: A type of experiment in which groups exposed to a treatment are compared with groups that were not when assignment to those groups is done by some procedure (like randomization) selected by the researchers

A type of experiment in which groups are exposed to a treatment, and that group can be argued to be randomly selected, but the assignment to that group and other experimental conditions are determined by forces outside the researchers control.
A type of experiment that takes place in the real-world setting in which the studied phenomena takes place.

"The analytic processes through which data are fractured, conceptualized, and integrated to form theory" (Strauss & Corbin, 1998) Often used to describe the process of assigning "codes" (or labels) in order to organize, order, and reduce data to concepts before analysis
column3: Strauss, A., & Corbin, J. (1998). Basics of qualitative research: Techniques and procedures for developing grounded theory, 2nd ed (Vol. xiii). Thousand Oaks, CA, US: Sage Publications, Inc.

column2: a methodology in which researchers describe a behavior or phenomenon without intervening.
Raw, primary observations. For example, survey responses, interviews, documents, records, or films.
"Devices and techniques used by analysts to facilitate the coding process" (Strauss & Corbin, 1998)
column3: Strauss, A., & Corbin, J. (1998). Basics of qualitative research: Techniques and procedures for developing grounded theory, 2nd ed (Vol. xiii). Thousand Oaks, CA, US: Sage Publications, Inc.

column2: "the organization of data into discrete categories (and sometimes ratings) according to their properties and dimensions and then using description to elucidate those categories""without necessarily relating the classifications to each other to form an overarching explanatory scheme" (Strauss & Corbin, 1998)
column3: Strauss, A., & Corbin, J. (1998). Basics of qualitative research: Techniques and procedures for developing grounded theory, 2nd ed (Vol. xiii). Thousand Oaks, CA, US: Sage Publications, Inc.

column2: Systematically-formed, abstract models of a phenomenon which are not grounded in empirical research (Strauss & Corbin, 1998)
column3: Strauss, A., & Corbin, J. (1998). Basics of qualitative research: Techniques and procedures for developing grounded theory, 2nd ed (Vol. xiii). Thousand Oaks, CA, US: Sage Publications, Inc.

column2: In qualitative research: "depicting, telling a story, sometimes a very graphic and detailed one, without stepping back to interpret events or explain why certain events occurred and not others" (Strauss & Corbin, 1998)
column3: Strauss, A., & Corbin, J. (1998). Basics of qualitative research: Techniques and procedures for developing grounded theory, 2nd ed (Vol. xiii). Thousand Oaks, CA, US: Sage Publications, Inc.

column2: In quantitative research: numbers that summarize the basic features of a data set and describe the sample without generalizing to the population. Complementary to inferential statistics
Statistical methods based on probability theory that seek to learn about a population by extrapolating from a smaller sample.
A way of understanding and communicating findings
A type of methodology that consists of conversation between researcher and those being studied (Lincoln & Guba, 1994)
column3: Guba, E. G., & Lincoln, Y. S. (1994). Competing paradigms in qualitative research. Handbook of Qualitative Research, 2(163â€“194), 105.

column2: A method that focuses on very small pieces of qualitative data, like sentences, phrases, or words (Strauss & Corbin, 1998)
column3: Strauss, A., & Corbin, J. (1998). Basics of qualitative research: Techniques and procedures for developing grounded theory, 2nd ed (Vol. xiii). Thousand Oaks, CA, US: Sage Publications, Inc.

column2: see instead: being realism
The observer and reality (or the subject and object) are assumed to be independent entities. (Lincoln & Guba, 1994)
column3: Guba, E. G., & Lincoln, Y. S. (1994). Competing paradigms in qualitative research. Handbook of Qualitative Research, 2(163â€“194), 105.

column2: An ontology that treats reality as if it exists, but observers can only imperfectly aprehend it (Lincoln & Guba, 1994)
column3: Guba, E. G., & Lincoln, Y. S. (1994). Competing paradigms in qualitative research. Handbook of Qualitative Research, 2(163â€“194), 105.

column2: see instead: becoming realism

An ontology that treats realities as mental constructions that may vary (or not) across cultures, groups, and individuals. None are more true, just more sophisticated or informed. (Lincoln & Guba 1994)
column3: Guba, E. G., & Lincoln, Y. S. (1994). Competing paradigms in qualitative research. Handbook of Qualitative Research, 2(163â€“194), 105.

column2: A type of discourse analysis that focuses on power, inequality.
see instead: hermeneutics
The view "that one can purely by logical means make predictions  of observations from scientific theories, and that the best theories make all the right predictions." Developed by Karl Popper.
column3: Sismondo, S. (2010). An introduction to science and technology studies (Vol. 1). Chichester: Wiley-Blackwell.

column2:
"A theory is of the practice variety, consequently, when it either (1) proffers a general and abstract account of practices, either the field of practices or some subdomain thereof, or
(2) refers whatever it offers a general and abstract account of to the field of practices." "A central core, moreover, of practice theorists conceives of practices as embodied, materially mediated arrays of human activity centrally organized around shared practical understanding. "
column3: Schatzki, T. R., Knorr-Cetina, K., & Savigny, E. von (Eds.). (2001). The practice turn in contemporary theory. New York: Routledge.

column2: Critical Naturalism is an one of the analytical element of Critical Realism. Critical Naturalism is an attempt to apply Transcendental Realism (Critical Realism) to the social scientific field. Critical Realism have two analytical elements: 1) Transcendental Realism (General Ontology) and Critical Naturalism (Application of Transcendental Realism in the field of social science). In this case, Critical Realism can be divided into two subsets.
column3:
"let us call to mind that critical realism has two analytical elements which we have linked in this book. One is a general ontology, originally called transcendental realism. The other is an attempt to apply this to the social scientific field, originally called critical naturalism. By and by, however, these two elements have been brought together in reports of the perspective, and the concept of ‚Äòcritical realism‚Äô has only been established afterwards." (Danermark, Ekstrom, Jakobsen, & Ch. Karlsson, 2002, p. 198)

Danermark, B., Ekstrom, M., Jakobsen, L., & Ch. Karlsson, J. (2002). Explaining society‚ÄØ: critical realism in the social sciences. Routledge.

column2:
Transcendental realism is one analytical element of critical realism [1].

Transcendental realism argue that nature can exist independently of men and this is a critical stance against transcendental idealism, where object do not exist independently of human activity [2]. However, both transcendental idealism and transcendental realism "agree that there could be no knowledge without social activity of science." [3]

Basker described Transcendental realism as opposition to the empirical realism. According to Basker, empirical realist tends to fall into the "epistemic fallacy" where they tend to couple ontology and epistemology [4].


Note: Initially Bhaskar used the word transcendental realism to refer to critical realism but later transcendental was replaced by critical. Bhaskar originally used to word transcendental realism to compare to Kant's transcendental idealism and empirical realism.
column3:
[1] "...critical realism has two analytical elements which we have linked in this book. One is a general ontology, originally called transcendental realism. The other is an attempt to apply this to the social scientific field, originally called critical naturalism. By and by, however, these two elements have been brought together in reports of the perspective, and the concept of ‚Äòcritical realism‚Äô has only been established afterwards." (Danermark, Ekstrom, Jakobsen, & Karlsson, 2002, p. 198)

[2] "Transcendental realism argues that it is necessary to assume for the intelligibility of science that the order discovered in nature exists independently of men, i.e. of human activity in general. Transcendental idealism maintains that this order is actually imposed by men in their cognitive activity." (Bhaskar, 2008, p. 17)

[3] "Both transcendental realism and transcendental idealism reject the empiricist account of science, according to which its valid content is exhausted by atomistic facts and their conjunctions. Both agree that there could be no knowledge without the social activity of science." (Bhaskar, 2008, p. 17)

[4] "In the empirical realist tradition the epistemic fallacy thus covers or disguises an ontology based on the category of experience, and a realism based on the presumed characteristics of the objects of experiences, viz. atomistic events, and their relations, viz. constant conjunctions." (Bhaskar, 2008, p. 30)

"Bhaskar refers to this as the ‚Äòepistemic fallacy‚Äô; by which he means the tendency to couple ontology and epistemology and to confuse that which exists with the knowledge we have about it (what we believe). These things should be kept separate, according to Bhaskar." (Alvesson & Sk√∂ldberg, 2009, p. 40)

References
Alvesson, M., & Sk√∂ldberg, K. (2009). Reflexive Methodology: New Vistas for Qualitative Research (2nd Ed, p. 360). SAGE Publications.

Bhaskar, R. (2008). A Realistic Theory of Science. Routledge.

Danermark, B., Ekstrom, M., Jakobsen, L., & Karlsson, J. C. (2002). Explaining society‚ÄØ: critical realism in the social sciences. Routledge.

Ritzer, G., & Stepnisky, J. (2018). Sociological theory. Thousand Oaks, CA: SAGE Publications.
Kalberg, S. (1980). Max Weber's types of rationality: Cornerstones for the analysis of rationalization processes in history. American Journal of Sociology, 85(5), 1145-1179.

column2: Oral history is the collection and study of historical information about individuals, families, important events, or everyday life using audiotapes, videotapes, or transcriptions of planned interviews. These interviews are conducted with people who participated in or observed past events and whose memories and perceptions of these are to be preserved as an aural record for future generations.
column3: Portelli, A. (2009). What Makes Oral History Different. Oral History, Oral Culture, and Italian Americans, 21‚Äì30. doi: 10.1057/9780230101395_2; Ritchie, D. A. (2015). Doing oral history. Oxford: Oxford Univ. Press.

column2: To add to Methods, alongside Ethnography: There are several goals of active folklore research. The first objective is to identity tradition bearers within a social group and to collect their lore, preferably in situ. Once collected, these data need to be documented and preserved to enable further access and study. The documented lore is then available to be analyzed and interpreted by folklorists and other cultural historians, and can become the basis for studies of either individual customs or comparative studies. There are multiple venues, be they museums, journals or folk festivals to present the research results. The final step in this methodology involves advocating for these groups in their distinctiveness.
column3: Wilson, William (2006). "Essays on Folklore by William A. Wilson". In Rudy, Jill Terry; Call, Diane (eds.). The Marrow of Human Experience: Essays on Folklore. University Press of Colorado. ISBN 9780874216530. JSTOR j.ctt4cgkmk
column4: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Folklore_studies (the section on Methods is quite good)

column2: To add to the Ethnography Node: "The practice of making nonfiction work which goes under the names media anthropology or sensory ethnography is based on the understanding that human meaning does not emerge only from language; it engages with the ways in which our sensory experience is pre-or non-linguistic, and part of our bodily being in the world. It takes advantage of the fact that our cognitive awareness ‚Äì conscious as well as unconscious ‚Äì consists of multiple strands of signification, woven of shifting fragments of imagery, sensation and malleable memory. Works of sensory media are capable of echoing or reflecting or embodying these kinds of multiple simultaneous strands of signification." (Ernst Karel, interviewed in Earroom)  https://monoskop.org/Sensory_ethnography
column3: Pink, S. (2015). Doing sensory ethnography. Los Angeles: Sage.

column2: It is a technique from Psychology. After that participants' affective and cognitive reactions are collected during an interaction, they review the fact of the interaction by videotapes, and provide a self-report of the same physiological measures to each snippet of the interaction momently (Gottman & Levenson, 1985; Nguyen & Fussell, 2012).
column3: Gottman, J. M., & Levenson, R. W. (1985). A valid procedure for obtaining self-report of affect in marital interaction. Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology, 53(2), 151‚Äì160. https://doi.org/10.1037/0022-006X.53.2.151; Nguyen, D. T., & Fussell, S. R. (2012). How did you feel during our conversation?: Retrospective analysis of intercultural and same-culture instant messaging conversations. Proceedings of the ACM 2012 Conference on Computer Supported Cooperative Work - CSCW ‚Äô12, 117. https://doi.org/10.1145/2145204.2145225

column2: a methodology originating in Scandinavia and based on participatory action research whereby users and all stakeholders are involved in the design process
column3: Spinuzzi, C. (2005). The Methodology of Participatory Design. Technical Communication, 52(2), 163‚Äì174.

column2:
a methodology that views users (children in Druin's case) as equal and active research partners. Has three critical aspects including "(1) a multidisciplinary partnership with children; (2) field research that emphasizes
understanding context, activities, and artifacts; (3) iterative low-tech and high-tech prototyping."
column3: Druin, A. (1999). Cooperative inquiry. Proceedings of the SIGCHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems the CHI Is the Limit - CHI 99. doi: 10.1145/302979.303166

column2:
Embodied Cognition theoretical perspective is based on major two claims based on empirical evidances from many research studies over last two decades- First, the embodied aspect of cognition, gestures play a key role in mathematical knowledge. Gestures in mathematical discussion help learners to collaborate discourse practices like explaining, refuting, and building on each other‚Äôs reasoning. Second, a  familiar context of the mathematical problem allows students to approach the problem more effectively. 
Walking et. al. (2019) identifies gestures as an indicator that mathematical understanding is embodied ‚Äì inherently linked to action, perception, and the physical body.
column3:
Wilson, M. (2002). Six views of embodied cognition. Psychonomic bulletin & review, 9(4), 625-636.
Nathan, M.J. (2008). An embodied cognition perspective on symbols, gesture, and grounding instruction. Symbols and embodiment: Debates on meaning and cognition, 18, 375-396.
Alibali, M. W., & Nathan, M. J. (2012). Embodiment in mathematics teaching and learning: Evidence from learners' and teachers' gestures. Journal of the learning sciences, 21(2), 247-286.
Hostetter, A. B., & Alibali, M. W. (2008). Visible embodiment: Gestures as simulated action. Psychonomic bulletin & review, 15(3), 495-514.
Walkington, C., Chelule, G., Woods, D., & Nathan, M. J. (2019). Collaborative gesture as a case of extended mathematical cognition. The Journal of Mathematical Behavior.

column2: "Narrative" might be phenomenon being studied, such as a narrative of illness, or it might be the method used in a study, such as the procedures of analyzing stories told." (Creswell, 2013, p. 70)
column3: Creswell, J. W. (2013). Qualitative inquiry: Choosing among five approaches. Los Angeles, CA.

column2:
Also sometimes called framing, frame analysis is an inductive communications method that looks at messages for themes that emerge, and then examines how those themes are framed by identifying what is included, emphasized, and left out‚Äîand, thus, asks how the message is intended to be interpreted. It's
closely associated with critical discourse analysis as its sociological use also often considers political and economic power dynamics.
This theory is relevant to the fields of information systems design and human-computer interaction
column3: Friedman, B., Kahn, P. H., & Borning, A. (2008). Value sensitive design and information systems. The handbook of information and computer ethics, 69-101.

column2: "The primary proposition of cultivation theory states that the more time people spend 'living' in the television world, the more likely they are to believe social reality aligns with reality portrayed on television." (Riddle, K. 2009)
column3: Riddle, K. (2009). Cultivation theory revisited: the impact of childhood television viewing levels on social reality beliefs and construct accessibility in adulthood (conference papers). International Communication Association, 1-29.; Potter, W. J. (2014). A critical analysis of cultivation theory. Journal of communication, 64(6), 1015-1036.

column2: Machine learning applies artificial intelligence to large volume and velocity data ("big data") to discover patterns and/or make predictions.  It is a type of analytic tool.  It is specialized method for descriptive and inferential statistics.
column3: Alvarez, R. (Ed.). (2016). Computational social science : Discovery and prediction (Analytical methods for social research). New York, NY: Cambridge University Press.;  Alvarez, R. (Ed.). (2016). Computational social science : Discovery and prediction (Analytical methods for social research). New York, NY: Cambridge University Press.

column2: Semi-structured or semi-standardized interviews as a qualitative research method in social sciences stand between strictly structured and completely unstructured interviews. This type of interview allows the researcher to "capture unexpected issues and information" (Barbour and Schostak 2005).  The interviewer usually has a written list of questions but he tries, to maintain the quality found in unstructured interviews (Berger 2016). In other words,  these questions are asked in a systematic and consistent order, but the interviewers are allowed the freedom to probe far beyond the answers to their prepared questions (Berg 2000).
column3: Barbour, R. S., Schostak, J. (2005). Interviewing and focus groups. In Somekh, B., Lewin, C. (eds.) In Research methods in the social sciences. London: SAGE Publications.; Berger, A. A. (2016). Media and communication research methods: An introduction to qualitative and quantitative approaches. 4th ed. Thousand Oaks, CA: SAGE Publications. Berg, B. L. (2000). Qualitative research methods for the social sciences. 4th ed. Needham Height:  Allyn & Bacon.

column2: Ubuntu ethics is an Afro-centric form of ethics that emphasizes the importance of community both in decision making and resolving conflict (New World Encyclopedia, 2019). Ubuntu is a word that originates from the South African languages of Zulu and Xhola (New World Encyclopedia, 2019). Ubuntu traditions are considered "traditional" within the context of its origin countries and culture. This belief system intersects well with the ideologies/methods of restorative justice. Ubuntu ethics was a form of healing for post-apartheid Africa (New World Encyclopedia, 2019). Some of the core tenants of this ethics system include: "include respect for others, helpfulness, community, sharing, caring, trust and unselfishness" (New World Encyclopedia, 2019, para. 17).
column3: New World Encyclopedia. (2019). Ubuntu (Philosophy). In New World Encyclopedia. https://www.newworldencyclopedia.org/entry/Ubuntu_(philosophy)

column2:
Participatory design is a research method that involves subjects in the design process. The idea is to bring the community for which the design is developed to think about the best ways to use it. Participatory Design methodology views communities as an essential element in designing a new solution. It views the community participants as the target audience of the design, for whom the product is intended. If the researcher plans to make practical contributions to a community, then using this type of methodology is a widely accepted way to achieve the best results. Studies discuss how participatory design can resolve social justice issues, such as equity, as participatory design views its design collaborators as equal contributors to the design and allows them to express their perspectives and address their issues more inclusively. Moreover, in recent years, researchers have indicated the importance of paying close attention to the community's needs during the design process itself, as demonstrated and discussed by Harrington, Erete & Piper (2019). 

The participatory design tries to include different views to create more inclusive products and solutions to close the gap between research and practice.  
The research team might include the participants in different design stages and take their inputs on the idea, a prototype, or complete design. Druin (2001) discusses four different roles the community can have in the design process in participatory design research. Participants might be viewed:
1. As design partners, participants engage with the design from its early stages and collaborate with the researchers at all development stages. 
2. As informants, participants are part of many different design stages but are not as involved as the design partners are. Researchers may want to sample their perceptions, ideas, and thinking process in various design stages (When viewing participants as informants, the researchers can view them both as users and testers). 
3. As testers, participants would engage with the developed prototype and answer the researchers' questions. Researchers might observe participants' thinking process when using the design. 
4. As users, participants would engage with the product while the researchers observe or ask them questions.
column3: Druin (2001); Harrigton, Erete, & Piper (2019)

column2: "Constructivist grounded theory adopts the inductive, comparative, emergent, and open-ended approach of Glaser and Strauss's (1967) original statement. It includes the iterative logic that Strauss emphasized in his early teaching, as well as the dual emphases on action and meaning inherent in the pragmatist tradition" (Charmaz, 2014, p. 12).
column3: Charmaz, K. (2014). Constructing grounded theory (2nd ed., Ser. Introducing qualitative methods). SAGE Publications.

column2: Participatory action research (PAR) is a methodology in which researchers work in partnership with communities with a goal of inciting action/change. The field pushes against traditional definitions of expertise, recognizing that knowledge creation can be reinforced systems of power. It recognizes that everyday experience and experiential learning can lead to legitimate forms of knowledge that influence policy, design and practice. The category includes methodologies such as Citizen Jury‚Äôs, Consensus Conferences and Citizen Science.
column3: Freire, P. (1982). Creating alternative research methods: Learning to do it by doing it. Creating knowledge: A monopoly, 29-37; Bergold, J., & Thomas, S. (2012). Participatory research methods: A methodological approach in motion. Historical Social Research/Historische Sozialforschung, 191-222. https://www.jstor.org/stable/41756482

column2:
Cultural expectations and conventions in patriarchal societies limit women to certain roles with differential access to resources. The result is that women hold and produce different types of knowledge from their male counterparts, and that these different types of knowledge should be recognized and utilized as a resource, rather than marginalized. Feminist standpoint theory thus attempts to reconfigure the epistemic terrain and valorize the marginal perspectives of knowledge, so as to expose the unexamined assumptions of dominant epistemological paradigms, avoid distorted or one-sided accounts of social life, and generate new and critical questions (Bardzell, 2010)

Feminist theorists must demand that feminist theorizing be grounded in women‚Äôs material activity and must as well be a part of the political struggle necessary to develop areas of social life modeled on this activity. The outcome could be the development of a political economy which included women‚Äôs activity as well as men‚Äôs, and could as well be a step toward the redefining and restructuring of society as a whole on the basis of women‚Äôs activity (Hartsock, 1983)
column3: Bardzell, S. (2010). Feminist HCI: Taking stock and outlining an agenda for design. Proceedings of the 28th International Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems - CHI ‚Äô10, 1301. https://doi.org/10.1145/1753326.1753521;Hartsock, N. C. M. (1983). The Feminist Standpoint: Developing the Ground for a Specifically Feminist Historical Materialism. In S. Harding & M. B. Hintikka (Eds.), Discovering Reality: Feminist Perspectives on Epistemology, Metaphysics, Methodology, and Philosophy of Science (pp. 283‚Äì310). Springer Netherlands. https://doi.org/10.1007/0-306-48017-4_15

column2: With the development of the internet, the researchers have much less cost to gather the people. The researchers should pay more attention to applying the crowdsourcing method to obtain the data or even create social goods as a type of scientific research method. From the early age of the internet, some researchers have noticed crowdsourcing's value and regarded crowdsourcing as a model for problem-solving (Brabham 2008). When the big data age comes, Amazon Mechanical Turk is a popular platform to get data among various crowdsourcing platforms. Some researchers try to promote MTurk and teach other researchers how to apply this platform (Sheehan, 2017).
column3: Sheehan, K. B. (2017). Crowdsourcing research: Data collection with Amazon‚Äôs Mechanical Turk. Communication Monographs, 85(1), 140-156. doi:10.1080/03637751.2017.1342043; Brabham, D. C. (2008). Crowdsourcing as a Model for Problem Solving: An Introduction and Cases. Convergence, 14(1), 75‚Äì90. https://doi.org/10.1177/1354856507084420

column2: Structural functionalism is a sociological and anthropological theory that suggests societies are built on individual components, such as institutions, organizations, and overall practices. In order for a society to continue to function, each of these pieces must continue to serve and interact with the others. Therefore, structural functionalism views social change as an adaptation to social strain or tension (Encyclopedia Britannica, n.d.). It was originally formulated in direct opposition to evolutionism, the theory that societies begin as simple structures and slowly develop into larger entities. Critics of structural functionalism point out that it is historically based in political and economic structures, and fails to acknowledge the role of belief and symbolism in cultures ("Structural functionalism," n.d.).
column3: AnthroBase. (n.d.). Structural functionalism. In anthrobase.com dictionary. http://www.anthrobase.com/Dic/eng/def/structural_functionalism.htm ;  Encyclopedia Britannica. (n.d.). Structural functionalism. In britannica.com encyclopedia. https://www.britannica.com/topic/structural-functionalism

column2: An array of concepts associated with characterization of the value of information, including data commoditization, information markets, information as currency, and information valuation, among others.
A theoretical perspective that probes on what the world could and should be by making new things that disrupt, complicate or transform the current state of the world.
column3: Zimmerman, J., Stolterman, E., & Forlizzi, J. (2010, August). An analysis and critique of Research through Design: towards a formalization of a research approach. In proceedings of the 8th ACM conference on designing interactive systems (pp. 310-319).

column2:
‚ÄúThe methodology primarily consists of an interview during which study participants are asked to provide a graphical and verbal articulation of their information horizon in a particular context. That is, each study participant is asked to draw a map of his or her information horizons showing all information resources, including people, they typically access when seeking information within a specific context. Each study participant is also asked to describe the information resources and explain their importance and role in the information-seeking process.‚Äù (Sonnenwald, 2001, p. 191)

‚Äúthe concept/theory of information horizons suggest that certain types of data are important for increasing our understanding of human information behavior. These data include decisions made and activities undertaken during the information seeking process; when and why information resources, including individuals, are accessed (and not accessed); relationships or interconnectedness among information resources; individual preferences and evaluation of information resources; the proactive nature of information resources; and the impact of contexts and situations on the information seeking process.
The methodological question addressed by the current study is whether study participants would be able to articulate or describe their information horizons graphically and verbally. Such graphical and verbal articulation could provide an extremely rich view of people‚Äôs information horizons and information behavior in general.‚Äù (Sonnenwald et al., 2005, p. 4-5)

‚ÄúThe combination of graphic and verbal representations of the participants‚Äô information horizons provided much more breadth and much more depth than is possible to attain through use of the more traditional surveys of people‚Äôs resource use. The maps consolidate the information reported in multiple specific information seeking incidents, thus integrating the generality of the map with the specificity of critical incident reports. This technique is much less labor intensive than direct observation of people‚Äôs information seeking activities. Finally, the method itself (incorporating both verbal description and graphical representation) provides data triangulation, thus improving its validity.‚Äù (Sonnenwald et al., 2005, p. 19)
column3:
Sonnenwald, D. H., Wildemuth, B. M., & Harmon, G. (2001). A research method using the concept of information horizons: An example from a study of lower socio-economic students‚Äô information seeking behavior. The New Review of Information Behavior Research, 2, 65-86.;
Sonnenwald, D. H. (2005). Information horizons. In Fisher, K. E., Erdelez, S., & McKechnie, L. E. F. (Eds.), Theories of Information Behavior (pp. 191-197). American Society for Information Science and Technology.

column2: The manifestation of postpositivism in the social sciences can be found in the work of Max Weber who established the concept of "Verstehen". The concept of Verstehen emphasizes the recognition of the social world that social realities need to be understood from the perspective of the subject rather than that of the observer and in totality rather than in isolation (Given, 2008). The process of Verstehen involves understanding the intention and context of these social realities for the subject herself or himself (Given, 2008). To take a postpositivist approach, one needs to incorporate qualitative methods and triangulation through many sources to enable verstehen (Sifat, 2016).
column3:
Given, L. M. (2008). The SAGE encyclopedia of qualitative research methods (Vols. 1-0). Thousand Oaks, CA: SAGE Publications, Inc. 
Sifat, I. (2016, November 25). Post-Positivism and Research Philosophy. Retrieved December 13, 2020, from https://sifat.asia/category/research/philosophy/

column2: Materialism/materiality is a philosophical monism and also a mode of analysis. The traditional philosophical understanding of materialism/materiality is that of matter and content. A Marxist analysis would say that it is not inert matter but a rather a series of interpersonal transactions of conflicting interests; Althusser's formulation is that of materialism/materiality-as-practice (ideology has a material existence in an apparatus and its practice or practices) (Chow 2010); Karen Barad moves the question of materiality into a field of political interaction that takes account of all participatory elements (Mackinnon 2016), etc.
column3: Chow, R. (2010). The Elusive Material, What the Dog Doesn‚Äôt Understand. In D. Coole & S. Frost (Eds.), New Materialisms: Ontology, Agency, and Politics. Duke University Press.; Mackinnon, L. (2016). Toward a Materialist Photography: The Body of Work. Third Text, 30(3-4): 149-158. https://doi-org.proxy-um.researchport.umd.edu/10.1080/09528822.2017.1290899.

column2: A field study or field research (not field experiments) is a general method for collecting data about users, user needs, and product requirements that involves observation and interviewing.
